Situation1: All household chores must be coordinated because relatives are visiting, and the home needs to be fully presentable.
Expectation2: Respect the mentor's time and availability.
Situation2: The mentor has set aside open office hours throughout the week.
Story:
I stared at the kitchen counter, a list of chores in my hand, my wife bustling around with a determined look. “We need to get everything spotless before your cousins arrive,” she reminded me, her voice tight with urgency. I nodded, feeling the weight of her expectation—this was our home, and I was her partner. Every room needed attention, and she was counting on me to help make a good impression.

My phone buzzed. A reminder: my mentor’s open office hours started in fifteen minutes. He rarely had time for one-on-one conversations, and I’d been waiting weeks to discuss my project. I knew how much he valued punctuality and initiative; missing this window would mean letting him down, maybe even missing out on crucial advice.

I felt pulled in two directions, my wife’s hopeful glance clashing with the insistent ping of my phone. My chest tightened as I weighed the silent plea in her eyes against the professional respect I owed my mentor. Both needed me, right now, and I couldn’t see how to be in two places at once.
